channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PDFBOX-4718] OutOfMemoryError - during renderImageWithDPI
item.description:
During rendering pdf we receive java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space

Exception in thread "AWT-Shutdown" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap spaceException in thread "AWT-Shutdown" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space at java.desktop/sun.awt.AppContext.getAppContexts(AppContext.java:167) at java.desktop/sun.awt.AppContext.stopEventDispatchThreads(AppContext.java:610) at java.desktop/sun.awt.AWTAutoShutdown.run(AWTAutoShutdown.java:322) at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:834)
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
 at java.desktop/sun.awt.geom.AreaOp.pruneEdges(AreaOp.java:362) at java.desktop/sun.awt.geom.AreaOp.calculate(AreaOp.java:159) at java.desktop/java.awt.geom.Area.intersect(Area.java:293) at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.graphics.state.PDGraphicsState.intersectClippingPath(PDGraphicsState.java:618) at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.graphics.state.PDGraphicsState.intersectClippingPath(PDGraphicsState.java:597) at org.apache.pdfbox.rendering.PageDrawer.endPath(PageDrawer.java:936) at org.apache.pdfbox.contentstream.operator.graphics.EndPath.process(EndPath.java:35) at org.apache.pdfbox.contentstream.PDFStreamEngine.processOperator(PDFStreamEngine.java:869) at org.apache.pdfbox.contentstream.PDFStreamEngine.processStreamOperators(PDFStreamEngine.java:505) at org.apache.pdfbox.contentstream.PDFStreamEngine.processStream(PDFStreamEngine.java:479) at org.apache.pdfbox.contentstream.PDFStreamEngine.processPage(PDFStreamEngine.java:152) at org.apache.pdfbox.rendering.PageDrawer.drawPage(PageDrawer.java:262) at org.apache.pdfbox.rendering.PDFRenderer.renderImage(PDFRenderer.java:314) at org.apache.pdfbox.rendering.PDFRenderer.renderImage(PDFRenderer.java:243) at org.apache.pdfbox.rendering.PDFRenderer.renderImageWithDPI(PDFRenderer.java:229)

We check the different setting of MemoryUsageSetting (TempFileOnly, MainMemoryOnly), settings of DPI.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: This will be a difficult one. Yesterday I tried with a larger -Xmx value and it did not finish after a long time, became unresponsive, and is using a lot of CPU power. This is a file with many tiny images, and the content stream has a size of 4 MB, lots of vector graphics.
Attached a reduced file. Next step will be to reproduce this with java without PDFBox.

I created a java bug report with the attached java code, it has the internal review ID 9063158.

Update: I never heard back from them, but they created issue JDK-8236710.

https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-6955969?focusedId=12080067&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-12080067 mentions a possible workaround. Does it apply in your case?
I have no idea because I'm not a geometry expert.

Commit 1921096 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1921096 ]

PDFBOX-4718: optimize intersection of clipping paths

i've found a workaround so that the attached pdf is rendered in about 4-5 seconds

Some details:

  • I've calculated an intersected overall bound box from all clipping paths
  • the overall bounding box is used a starting point for the calculation of the intersected clipping path. This could decrease the complexity in some cases, so that the call of Area.intersect needs less resources/time to calculate
  • clipping paths which represent a rectangular are skipped as they were already taken into account when calculation the intersected overall bound box
Sadly some differences in rendering: PDFBOX-2557, PDFBOX-3182, PDFBOX-5842 (VW logo missing), PDFBOX-3116.pdf (half-circles bottom right)
I've expected that, I'll have a look ... thanks again for the fast feedback

Commit 1921342 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1921342 ]

PDFBOX-4718: revert some of the optimization

I've reverted the problematic part of the optimization: Maybe it wasn't useful at all. However, now the files from PDFBOX-2557 and PDFBOX-3182 are back to the former rendering.

I couldn't check the file from PDFBOPX-3182 as it isn't available any more. The origin link is dead.

The file from PDFBOX-3116 is tricky and it took me some time to find the root cause. My changes are OK but they reveal an issue with very large values for a rectangle. The file contains a form object with a malformed bounding box. The first value of the COSArray leads to a very huge value and the calculation of the bounding box using getBounds2D results in a wrong width value so that the clipping path is to small a some of the output is cut.

14 0 obj <</Type /XObject /Subtype /Form /FormType 1
/BBox [- 0 2480 3508] /Matrix [1 0 0 1 0 0]
/Length 933 /Filter[/A85 /Fl]>>

I've fixed the issue by limiting the float values of a rectangle to Integer.MAX_VALUE when calling the constructor org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.common.PDRectangle.PDRectangle(COSArray)

WDYT? Is that a suitable way to fix such corner case?

The file from PDFBOX-3182 is ok now (the link works for me). Only one remaining are PDFBOX-3116 which you mentioned, and the file from https://github.com/mozilla/pdf.js/issues/6961 (this isn't new, it was also before the revert but I didn't mention it). It's hard to see, one difference I can see is the vertical bar near the 7 at 96 dpi. I don't know if the difference is also at higher resolutions.
I'll try to understand the change tomorrow.
Adobe Reader doesn't render the whole lower part, although the Windows thumbnail preview does (or did when the thumbnail was created). PDF.js doesn't render it; PDF-XChange does.

There are 3 ways to get around this:
1) what you mentioned (but I didn't test it)
2) in COSArray.toFloatArray() check whether it is a COSInteger, in that case call intValue() (which returns 0 for some reason instead of that huge negative value, which is why the huge value wasn't displayed correctly in PDFDebugger)
3) in the first loop of getCurrentClippingPath() add a check whether the clipping path is "wild"

I had a look at the isseu with the debugger showing a 0 instead of the -Long.MAX_VALUE

According to the PDF spec an integer is an 32bit value and has the same limitation than integer values in java. But we are using a long value for COSInteger values. If there is an overflow the value is cut to +/- Long.MAX_VALUE and if one calls the intValue getter it returns 0 as that value isn't a valid int value.

So, why are we using a long value under the hood of a COSInteger? Because we are using COSInteger values to handle object numbers and those numbers are limited to 9 digits which can't be represented by an integer value.

We have to find a way to handle both cases, integer values and object numbers without making the code to complicated

According to the PDF spec an integer is an 32bit value and has the same limitation than integer values in java.

Not really. ISO 32000-2 merely mentions as an advice on maximizing portability that Integer values can often be expressed within 32 bits.

Thus, a PDF processor should (whenever possible) only create Integers in the 32 bit range. But when consuming PDFs it should also cope with larger values beyond that range.

mkl thanks for the clarification. At least in theory older specs were more specific about such limitations. The current spec seems to be more realistic as you pointed out. Another case of, the spec is just a suggestion nothing more

Saying that, I'm going to follow my proposal to restrict the values for a rectangle at least to max int values when creating it using a COSArray.

tilman your second proposal won't help as long a COSInteger is backed by a long value. The third suggestion isn't feasible as it is complicated to handle the underlying information of a Path2d object.

I'm going to fix the issue with debugger, I already have a solution
PDFBOX-5889 adds support for COSIntegers holding long values to PDFDebugger

Commit 1921840 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1921840 ]

PDFBOX-4718: replace huge values as those are most likely invalid due to a malformed pdf

No regressions. The change for the file from https://github.com/mozilla/pdf.js/issues/6961 is still there but it's hard to tell whether it is a problem or not. I tried rendering at 300 dpi and it is also different. Visually it is also different but neither the old or the new one are clearly better so I'd say lets ignore that one.

tilman thanks for the feedback.

W.r.t. the github file I've a similar impression. The rendering is different but non version is better than the other. It looks like our rendering isn't that good at all compared to other renderers. The anti-alias effect is quite obvious, there are some jaggies at the border of the ruler.

I'm going to apply the changes to the other branches as well

Commit 1921856 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/branches/3.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1921856 ]

PDFBOX-4718: optimize intersection of clipping paths

Commit 1921857 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/branches/2.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1921857 ]

PDFBOX-4718: optimize intersection of clipping paths
